title: Grade 6 Math Data Management and Probability

questions.definition: Data that can only take specific values, such as the number of students in a class.
Data that can take any value within a range, such as the temperature over a day.
Data collected directly by the researcher through methods like surveys or experiments.
Data collected by someone else, often found in books, reports, or online sources.
A graph that uses rectangular bars to represent data, with the length of each bar proportional to its value.
A graph that uses points connected by lines to show trends or changes over time.
A circular chart divided into sectors, where each sector represents a portion of the whole.
A pattern or direction observed in data, such as an increase in sales over time.
An estimate of future outcomes based on trends observed in data.
The difference between the highest and lowest values in a data set.
The average of a data set, found by dividing the sum of all values by the total number of values.
The middle value in a data set when the values are arranged in order.
The value that appears most frequently in a data set.
A way of presenting data that makes it easy to understand and interpret.
A type of bar graph where the bars represent the frequency of data within equal intervals.
The likelihood of an event occurring, expressed as a fraction, decimal, or percentage.
The likelihood of an event occurring based on all possible outcomes.
The likelihood of an event occurring based on the results of an actual experiment.
One repetition of a probability experiment, such as flipping a coin.
A possible result of a probability experiment, such as rolling a 3 on a die.
The set of all possible outcomes in a probability experiment.
An event that will definitely happen; probability is 1 or 100%.
An event that cannot happen; probability is 0 or 0%.
An event that has a high chance of occurring but is not guaranteed.
An event that has a low chance of occurring but is not impossible.
A term used to describe a probability experiment where all outcomes are equally likely.
A term used to describe a probability experiment where certain outcomes are more likely than others.
The total number of repetitions in a probability experiment, affecting experimental probability.
A selection process where all outcomes have an equal chance of occurring.
A diagram used to show all possible outcomes of a probability experiment.
